moves.3. Bc4 e5: This isn't the regular move, I made this move to get more pressure on d4, for a knight outpost later, to free my DSB and to prevent white from playing Ng5 threatening a fork on f7
moves.4. d4: this is probably a pawn sacrifice for quicker developing, when I take I'll have a greater pawn pressure on the center, but he'll have a slight developing advantage, it as well makes it possible for his N to move to the g5 square, something I missed in the game
moves.4... cxd4 5. Ng5 Nh6: This is a weaker spot for the N but as white threatens Nf7 I have no other option except moving my queen, which I think would be weaker
moves.6. Qf3: Three attacks on the weak f7 square
moves.6... f6: Easy dealt with the threats, blocking the Q's way to f7, attacking the N on g7 and completing my pawn string
moves.7... d6: completely blocking my dark squared bisschop, but allowing Ng4, a better spot for the weak N on h6
moves.8. Na3: developing his N, since Nf3 isn't possible, although I think that Nd2 would've been stronger
moves.8... Ng4 9. Bd5 Nb4: My Ns now have 2 great outposts, I thought I could launch some attacks now, but i oversaw the following attack
moves.10. Bxb7 Bxb7 11. Qxg4: I now lost a pawn, however, white has given his strong bisschop for a strong knight, we shall see what turned out the most valuable
moves.12. O-O: easily overcame the threat while castling
moves.13. Qf3 d5: trying to get complete control of the center after 14.xd5 Qxd5 15.Qxd5 Nxd5 I have a better position and the strong LSB
moves.14... Bb7: protecting the pawn on d5 while also threatens to take e4, winning a pawn and probably even a greater pressure on the center
moves.15. Bxb4 Bxb4: bringing the DSB in the game
moves.17. exd5 Qxd5: I'm in control of the center and I'm threatening mate (Qxg2#)
moves.18. f3: stopped the mate, but weakens the kingside
moves.19. Qe4: I think I'm in advantage, so why wouldn't I trade Qs
moves.19... Qxe4 20. fxe4: renewed center pawn and a halfopen rank for white's rook
moves.21. Rfd1 Be2: infiltrating black's ranks, locking the rooks up on b1 and a1, because 22. Rc1 leads to 22. ... Bd2 23. Rb1
moves.23. Kf2: driving my LSB back, giving the rooks some place
moves.23... Ba6 24. Rbc1: I don't get this move, someone able to explain it?
moves.24... Bd2: attacking the rook and entering blacks other side
moves.25. Rcd1 Be3+ 26. Kg3 Rab8: taking the halfopen b-rank as well and attacking the pawn on b2
moves.27. b3 Bb7: here my opponent ran out of time, it was a great game, I wonder how it would've ended. please r&c
